content.webTitle: Poldark recap: series three, episode one – Ross gallops back into our lives

fields.headline: Poldark recap: series three, episode one – Ross gallops back into our lives
fields.bodyText: It was all births, deaths and marriages in this belter of a series opener. Lead the fallen souls of Cornwall! ‘Tis the coming of the shadow of death – and the curse of the black moon. Bang the drums and hear the waves crashing on the shore, Poldark’s back. There was enough going on in this episode to fuel an entire series of any other drama. And yet it all seemed fairly normal because this is just the pace at which things move in Trenwith and Nampara: let’s call it a lively mare’s gallop. At least there was a fiercely happy event at the heart of it all. “I can scarce believe this day has come ...” Me either. Sindy Doll and the Doctor were getting married. The joy on the doctor’s face! It was a wedding that felt almost delayed from last series, and long overdue. This episode did a good job of getting us back up to speed if we had forgotten the drowning of Francis; the long-standing feud between Evil George and Ross; Elizabeth and Ross’s ambiguous night of (coerced?) passion; and Aunt Agatha’s premonitions about a baby who would be coming suspiciously soon. Why, Elizabeth, all this heavy book-lifting and those three-mile walks; anyone would think you were trying to induce the birth. I felt like sending round a vindaloo to speed things up less dangerously. Of course, the long-awaited union of Dr Enys and Caroline Penvenen couldn’t be straightforward. But what a thing to happen on your pudding-fuelled honeymoon – a message to come and deliver Ross’s illegitimate child (surely?) “So much for my wedding night ...” How inconvenient. Demelza was the first to spot that this “fall” could hardly be coincidental; she knows the timing’s off. “You’ll go with Caroline?” That was an extraordinary moment. Demelza couldn’t be certain Ross wouldn’t head to Elizabeth. But somehow he restrained himself and stayed away, while by the light of the black moon the dark-haired Ross-like child was born. “I see the resemblance ...” Do you, Evil George? Are you sure? Ross knew the truth and looked as if he had eaten a wasp throughout most of this episode. It was very upsetting to see the last of Bergerac. What beautiful scenes from John Nettles; no one wanted Uncle Ray to die. I did wonder whether he would be quite so forgiving of Sindy Doll going behind his back to marry Dr Enys. But it made for a poignant scene. And so as one cast member expires (not forgetting Demelza’s annoying father too), others gallop in. And who be this, then? This be Demelza’s brother! (Is it me or are the Cornish accents extremely pronounced this series? Perhaps we’re just out of practice.) And this be Morwenna the governess, for one of the brothers to fall in love with. Other highlights? Geoffrey Charles is shaping up to be an excellent thorn in Evil George’s side. Prudie has a glint in her eye. And Horace the pug did a fine turn at the foot of the bed. It all bodes well. Pewter tankard award for bonkers brilliance as supporting actor Last series the pewter tankard went nowhere near Jack Farthing who plays Evil George Warleggan and that was a grave error. Farthing’s performance is so spot on that it’s almost easy to overlook, so genuine is our hatred of him. (He always reminds me of George Osborne. Maybe it’s the wavy plastic hair.) He was on top form here. Evil George’s latest missions include sending Geoffrey Charles to boarding school, founding the only bank in Cornwall and returning home from a hard day’s work with an unannounced governess in his carriage. And that’s before he’s taken over Poldark’s now-successful mining business. “There are a few things I’ve yet to purchase, Wheel Grace being one...” His face when Geoffrey Charles arrived home for his impromptu work experience at the mine was a picture. Long may he sup at the tankard with his dastardly ways. Classic Poldark lines “Blood. Name. Purpose. Fate ... It is coming sooner than we think.” Aunt Agatha does not need tarot cards to come across like a witch. “That child of yours, cursed under a black moon. No good shall come to him!” “You don’t miss your former wedded bliss?” “Like a ruptured spleen.” Well said, Prudie. Keep making those puddings. “Bliss is most assuredly Caroline.” Oh Dr Enys, no one but you could get away with a line this cheesy. Regulation reverse sexism bare chest moment The first series of Poldark rose to prominence largely thanks to the tabloid-busting qualities of The Torso. In the second series it receded into a rustic overshirt as Aidan Turner appeared to mutter in interviews that he was rather tired of the whole business. Instead of bare chest action this week there was a muscular stress-busting run on the beach. Meanwhile, it’s no secret that Demelza’s two brothers have been bussed in as Replacement Torso Action. (And before anyone complains below the line that this is reverse sexism or whatever: yes, yes, I know.) Next week “Ross Poldark has chosen to sever all ties ...” The baby is christened. Demelza’s younger brother has the dampeners put on his burgeoning crush on Morwenna. There are some bad military shenanigans. Verity cries. And there is a ball, and shooting! Pass the popcorn, I mean pudding.
